title: Enacts the "public employee safety enforcement act"
summary: Enacts the "public employee safety enforcement act"; enhances civil penalty provisions for willful or repeat employer violations of public employee safety and health act to $300 a day; defines "willful" for purposes of such provision to mean instances where the employer is aware of the applicable requirement or regulation and the condition or practice in violation or is aware that it is hazardous to employees and "repeat" violation as being a violation where the employer had previously been issued an order to comply for a substantially similar violation at the same site; provides civil penalties be paid and deposited into the state school construction fund.

       AN ACT to amend the labor law,  in  relation  to  enacting  the  "public
         employee safety enforcement act"

         THE  PEOPLE OF THE STATE OF NEW YORK, REPRESENTED IN SENATE AND ASSEM-
       BLY, DO ENACT AS FOLLOWS:

    1    Section 1. This act shall be known and may be  cited  as  the  "public
    2  employee safety enforcement act".
    3    S  2.  Paragraphs  a,  c and d of subdivision 6 of section 27-a of the
    4  labor law, paragraph a as amended by chapter 190 of the  laws  of  1990,
    5  paragraph  c as added by chapter 729 of the laws of 1980 and paragraph d
    6  as amended by chapter 145 of the laws of 1993, are amended  to  read  as
    7  follows:
    8    a.  If  the  commissioner  determines  that an employer has violated a
    9  provision of this section, or a safety or health standard or  regulation
   10  promulgated  under this section, he or she shall with reasonable prompt-
   11  ness issue to the employer an  order  to  comply  which  shall  describe
   12  particularly  the  nature  of the violation including a reference to the
   13  provision of this section, standard, regulation or order alleged to have
   14  been violated, shall fix a reasonable time for compliance and may estab-
   15  lish the penalty to be assessed for failure to correct the violation  by
   16  the  time  fixed for compliance. An employer who fails to correct a non-
   17  serious violation by the time fixed for compliance  may  be  assessed  a
   18  civil  penalty  of  up  to  fifty dollars per day until the violation is
   19  corrected. An employer who fails to correct a serious violation  by  the
   20  time  fixed  for compliance may be assessed a civil penalty of up to two
   21  hundred dollars per day until the violation is corrected.  CIVIL  PENAL-
   22  TIES  FOR  AN  EMPLOYER  FOUND TO BE A WILLFUL OR REPEAT VIOLATOR MAY BE
   23  ASSESSED FOR FAILURE TO CORRECT THE VIOLATION  BY  THE  TIME  FIXED  FOR
   24  COMPLIANCE  IN  AN AMOUNT UP TO THREE HUNDRED DOLLARS PER DAY, UNTIL THE
   25  VIOLATION IS CORRECTED. ANY CIVIL PENALTIES ASSESSED  PURSUANT  TO  THIS
   26  SUBDIVISION   SHALL   BE  PAID  AND  DEPOSITED  INTO  THE  STATE  SCHOOL
   27  CONSTRUCTION FUND. Pursuant to section 18(k) of the United States  Occu-
   28  pational Safety and Health Act of 1970 (Public Law[,] 91-596), a serious

    1  violation  shall be deemed to exist in a place of employment if there is
    2  a substantial probability that death  or  serious  physical  harm  could
    3  result  from  a  condition  which exists, or from one or more practices,
    4  means,  methods, operations, or processes which have been adopted or are
    5  in use, in such place of employment unless the  employer  did  not,  and
    6  could  not  with the exercise of reasonable diligence, know of the pres-
    7  ence of the violation. A non-serious violation shall be defined  as  any
    8  violation  that does not fall under the definition of serious violation.
    9  FOR PURPOSES OF THIS ARTICLE, AN EMPLOYER SHALL HAVE COMMITTED A  "WILL-
   10  FUL" VIOLATION IF:
   11    (I)  THE EMPLOYER WAS AWARE OF THE REQUIREMENTS OF THIS ARTICLE OR THE
   12  EXISTENCE OF THE APPLICABLE STANDARD OR REGULATION, AND WAS  ALSO  AWARE
   13  OF A CONDITION OR PRACTICE IN VIOLATION  OF THAT REQUIREMENT; OR
   14    (II)  AT  THE  TIME THE EMPLOYER COMMITTED THE VIOLATION, THE EMPLOYER
   15  WAS NOT AWARE OF ANY LEGAL REQUIREMENT BUT WAS AWARE THAT A CONDITION OR
   16  PRACTICE WAS HAZARDOUS TO THE SAFETY OR HEALTH OF EMPLOYEES.
   17    AN EMPLOYER SHALL HAVE COMMITTED A "REPEAT" VIOLATION IF THE  EMPLOYER
   18  HAD  BEEN ISSUED AN ORDER TO COMPLY PREVIOUSLY FOR A SUBSTANTIALLY SIMI-
   19  LAR VIOLATION AT THE SAME SITE AND NO APPEAL  OR  OTHER  PROCEEDING  FOR
   20  REVIEW  PROVIDED  FOR IN THIS ARTICLE SHALL THEN BE PENDING AND THE TIME
   21  FOR TAKING THEREOF SHALL HAVE EXPIRED.
   22    The commissioner shall not assess a penalty against  an  employer  for
   23  failure  to correct a violation of a standard which is the subject of an
   24  application for a PERMANENT OR temporary order granting a variance, or a
   25  violation OF A STANDARD which is the subject of a petition [to modify an
   26  order to comply] FOR MODIFICATION OF THE ABATEMENT DATE, provided howev-
   27  er, that upon issuance by the commissioner of  a  determination  denying
   28  such  variance  or petition to modify, or upon expiration of a temporary
   29  variance or modified compliance period, the time  fixed  for  compliance
   30  shall  recommence  and  the  employer  become  liable  for the penalties
   31  provided herein.
   32    c. Any employer, or other party affected by  a  determination  of  the
   33  [industrial]  commissioner  issued pursuant to this section may petition
   34  the industrial board of appeals for  review  of  such  determination  in
   35  accordance with section one hundred one of this chapter. Judicial review
   36  of  the  decision  of the industrial board of appeals may be obtained by
   37  any party affected by such decision by commencing a proceeding  pursuant
   38  to  article  seventy-eight  of  the  civil practice law and rules within
   39  sixty days after such decision is issued.
   40    d. If the time for compliance with an order of the commissioner issued
   41  pursuant to this section has elapsed, and the employer has not  complied
   42  with  the  provisions of the order, the commissioner shall seek judicial
   43  enforcement of such order by commencing a proceeding pursuant to article
   44  seventy-eight of the civil practice law and rules. Where an employer has
   45  complied with an order in all respects  other  than  the  payment  of  a
   46  penalty  imposed pursuant to this subdivision, the commissioner may file
   47  with the county clerk of the county where the employer has its place  of
   48  business  the  order  of  the  commissioner  [continuing] CONTAINING the
   49  amount of civil penalty found to be due. The filing of such order  shall
   50  have the full force and effect of a judgment duly docketed in the office
   51  of such clerk.  The order or decision may be enforced by and in the same
   52  manner,  and  with like effect, as that prescribed by the civil practice
   53  law and rules for the enforcement of a money judgment.
   54    S 3. This act shall take effect immediately and  shall  apply  to  all
   55  violations which occur on or after such date.
